Hi,

At 08:23 06/06/2004, Michael Gillam wrote:

>The next great leap forward just might be taking another big step backwards
>from what we rigidly define a priori.    Many systems today *rigidly* define
>the translation steps from genome to neural phenome.  How do we know that
>our translation of the genetic code of our organisms into neural structure
>is *the* optimal translation algorithm?  Perhaps other translation methods
>that use structures like homeotic boxes, replicative units, optimally
>balanced 'exxons' or others might more optimally step through topologies.
>Early work in Artificial Life strongly suggests that life was created and
>destroyed millions perhaps trillions of times.  Early life competed in a
>palette of likely vastly different translation methods of their genotypes to
>neural phenotypes.  Ultimately, the most rapid system for topological and
>phenotypical evolution likely triumphed and is the system we see today.

I should have read this before replying to Kenneth (except I've learned if 
I do that I forget my point :).

This is how nature has approached the issues I raised in my previous 
message.  It uses development rules, implemented in the genes, not as a 
direct blueprint for a neural net, but as a set of rules for how that net 
is assembled.  This has two advantages:

1) modularity -- because rules are applied by recognising existing 
structures and acting accordingly, a rule can be correctly applied to 
different sub-structures in the developing net, this allows it to support 
different sub-systems with a common framework (effectively via a common 
"interface" I mentioned in the other post)

2) robustness -- also because because rules are able to recognise existing 
structures, they have same ability to work-around any errors from previous 
developmental stages

>Call this process Genotypic Evolutionary Translation (GET).  Though many
>might dismiss GET as unnecessary, strong evidence points to its need.
>Perhaps most strongly is the fact that the only evolutionary system we know
>of that has successfully evolved sentience, had GET in its toolbox.  : )
>
>To me, creating GET is one of the pre-eminent intellectual challenges of
>neural-evolution today.  Kudos to the individual who solves this conundrum
>and is able to still obtain the evolutionary simulation speeds we see today.

Right with you, although I would not be tempted to follow nature too closely...

         Ian Badcoe
